title.justification: This is the title of the research paper.

extractions.description: The paper addresses the environmental impact of Federated Learning (FL) by proposing techniques and strategies to optimize FL for minimal carbon emissions, without sacrificing performance.

type.justification: The paper involves data-driven analysis and measurement to understand the carbon emissions of FL tasks and to propose optimizations.
type.quote: We put forth a model of the relationship between time-to-convergence, model performance, and carbon emissions. By leveraging our model, FL practitioners can effectively forecast the carbon emissions of their system before initiating the training process.

name.justification: The main focus of the paper is on Federated Learning and its carbon footprint.
name.quote: Federated learning (FL) is a distributed learning paradigm where a large number of client devices, such as smartphones, collectively train a machine learning model using data located on client devices.

name.justification: The paper explores Green AI principles within the context of Federated Learning.
name.quote: Green AI is a novel and important research area where carbon footprint is regarded as an evaluation criterion for AI, alongside accuracy, convergence speed, and other metrics.

name.justification: FedAvg is mentioned as the baseline for synchronous FL in the paper.
name.quote: The baseline implementation is FedAvg, whereas for asynchronous FL, it is FedBuff.

is_contributed.justification: FedAvg is used as a baseline method, not as a contribution of this paper.

is_executed.justification: The paper discusses the execution of FedAvg.

is_compared.justification: FedAvg is compared to asynchronous FL methods in the paper.
